titleStmt.title: M1-8, 4 of 10. [Anon: The loves & hates of the Elizabethans themselves...]. Holograph. In back [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 8-16. 9p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M1-8-4. [Anon: The loves & hates of the Elizabethans themselves...]. Holograph. In back [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 8-16. 9p.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

But by a queer The The trappings are there.
No generation had more anxiety to preserve
the substance from decay. The tombs
tombs They seem to pretend Their
graves are immaculately. One They defy death
with their great tombs. In life they
eat prodigously. They wear clothes that are
so heavy they can scarcely stand in them.
The outer life is as [illeg.]: as
great cloth of gold & marble can make it.
But the passions that hunt in the heart
are within are silent Until the dramatists
speak for them on the stage, they themselves are silent.

div.p:
Their attachment to the substance of the earth;
their body; their the greed with which they
acquire; their catalogues of property of
furniture; their perpetual [illeg.] for
their estates. This has survived, in
inventories, in little supplicating places;
in the For everything was their at th in
the gift of individuals, the family
It was the queen, or her nobles, who had the
[personal?] of patronage. The The
patron was in his prime. The book
depended on his favour. And yet in no

age can there have been a deeper gulf between the writer & the
society. The great who presumably Who is
to whom a young poet has
dedicated his sonnets? No body troubles to
ask. It is not a matter of importance it seems in
court circles. The plays are not discussed.
The world of writers is too remote from the
court. The loves & hates of these
descendants of the jugglers & minstrels are too
have no bearing upon the life of the nobles.
And the reason may be that the
early works of call for no breed no
out comment. The reason may be that
the dramatists were not destroying anything:
If these The indignation that, after the [fun?]

rage of those who felt that their won
world was being [civilised?]. People Great

half that function of the writer had

into [illeg.], into the figures of and :
in the adulterer; in the
the supper is laid; the cards are on the table; &

with their blanks, their riddles, their [suppressions?]
that can no longer be deciphered, are
give place to the outright downright speech.
In the play light all is evident & [outspoken?]. In

div.p:
Anonymity is fast dispersing. The play dramatist
is becoming self [anxious?]. The play is coming to be
the merits the And at some point, the
the dramatist is emerging from the old
juggler & the bear leader. He is becoming
freeing himself from the compulsion of the audience.
He is reserving A There is a The
bodily, the actual, If the body must still
dominate the little stage, if the
actual must be before the eye, & the

p.s: bodies must move violently, killing, [kniving?], goint to bed,

Killing, [kniving?], going to bed, adultery must still
be the staple of the play; but the staple of
of the play is the staple there must be
action; murder; violence; adultery. But by degrees
the dramatist is freeing himself from the stage.
He is adding to his resources. There are
His limits are still repressive. There
is

div.p:
And by degrees the dramatist sheds his
anonymity. He separates himself from his audience.
He wins a freedom. Though the stage exacts
with an in an ande in the to
He He wins the right sometimes to fame, in an

happens, to the motives, the hidden passions.
behind the action. What, he broods, in a

effect of mercy? – if, the sword is withheld
if the adulterers are [empouted?] not with death,
but with a guilty conscience? –

He chooses; discriminates. He is not And

The reader indeed is soon to be [appreciated?].
This is one of the delights lures of the Elizabethans
that they [revive?] the seer, the hearer, the actor in us.
If by Our anonym At some point – it
differs from age to age, – the reader is born;
for in the And anonymity
But what we have anonymity is a great power.
It has made one is a great possession –
a stage that has no writer the Elizabethan page:
the has kept the Elizabethan (Eth) drama [vigour? vision?]
unattached; it has given it a general [state?]
vitality; a lack of personality; as
if all the [hours?] of the [19th?] century had been

as if we could [slip?] the lives; the
[songs?]; the as a width, a bareness,

so that we forget something in ourselves when we
read it. We It gives us another being.
Only, as the unknown man who, it is said once
[held?] houses at the door, becomes more &
more dominant, as [wine?] we fallen &
stumble: we have to

Anonymity h gave us the ballads; it gave us the songs;
it gave us is a great preservative. To
know nothing except what is essential: to waste no
time prying & peeping: but to to be
know nothing – who wrote Lud Sing Cuccu
who wrote [Hilu Fan?] – who wrote the
[sonnets?] of [loys?], [mirthful], who but wrote to
[ful?] spring, dea love, death But That
And the stage with its bodies, its actors, taking
part for some time preserved this anonymous voice only until
when the [senses?] of the age, its hoard of
[unfilled?] patterns, the [illeg.] in the [armtials?]
of maids of [him?] & [curtain?]; pressed so hard on the
dramatist that he invented a speech
that could (cd.) give voice to everything.
Then, with , anonymity was destroyed..
Everything is known that can be known until
the stage becomes too small to act the
drama; & there is the book takes the place of the
stage play.

div.p:
, after all, has great privileges. He can is irrepressible.
He is not responsible. He is not self conscious. He is
free from infection. He can adventure & experiment.
He can borrow. He can jest speak on & on. He can
say what everyone feels: the common experiences
are his. No one asks that he shall be
idiosyncratic: that he shall stamp his
[dull?] [illeg.] on the old feelings: He shapes

speaks himself. For
the audience requires
[feels?] still part of the
play, insists on
repetition: it must
be [adu?] to sit, a shad
[thorn?], have a
story: & as poetry is
told in poetry, it
must have action:
[suicide?]: adultery.
The anticipation of the
audience to the
Elizabethan (Et) play was
[unfortunate?]. The
words will not
fit the speakers:
the [illeg.], the
[lapne?] confusion:
no one feels what
they say, the
emotion is often
plastered onto a
inappropriate figures.
But if one must
have violence, how
avoid this

div.p:
at a distance from the moment. Nobody cares what
his own private experience is. And so the
songs of repeat over & over again what
that Gather ye flowers while ye may; Death is
coming: Anon is never tired of celebrating
the Rose; never & that his [illeg.] is white;
he is a repetitious, co And since he is
content to say go unnoted, we cannot
pin him down, we cannot
separate him from his song. He has
thus an anonymous vitality, drawn from
other bodies, a perennial, common vigour.
Nor is he dead in ourselves. The crude early
dramas still persuade us to read – not to
find for the story. What comes next?
The fil dramatist Anon has little
care for the [Abound?] So we become
anonymous, in the early literature.
It is only later, when the pressure of emotion had
ca strewn up words, as a the fingers of a
the man at the cast
letters out of the bubbling metal, that
we lose this quality, to gain ––?––
everything it seems. For there flocking
the curtain [gives?] on rising. And now it has

on ; on &
By that time, there is nothing left unsaid:
the whole of this to test

The play has killed the stage. The stage has
become too small to act this drama.
Perhaps after centuries, the play will
renew itself, with Mozart in the ,
as with in . It never
lived again in England. The book, after that, takes the place of the play
& the is dead for ever.
